trial_identification.studytitle: To compare the effect of meals rich in saturated fat, canola oil and bran on postprandial levels of pro-inflammatory cytokines and interleukin-8 in obese and non-obese subjects
trial_identification.scientifictitle: To compare the effect of meals rich in saturated fat, canola oil and bran on postprandial levels of pro-inflammatory cytokines and interleukin-8 in obese and non-obese subjects

interventions.interventions: Administered 5 meals. Meal A, dehydrated potato (40 g); Meal B, dehydrated potato (40 g) plus saturated fat (1.6 g cream/kg body weight); Meal C, dehydrated potato (40 g) plus canola oil (0.6 g/kg body weight), Meal D, dehydrated potato (40 g) plus olive oil (0.6 g/kg body weight); Meal E, wheat bran (44 g) plus 40 ml trim milk. The meals all contained 2 cooked eggs. The potato was hydrated by addition of hot water. The meals were administered to an individual at the rate of one per week for 5 weeks. The subjects consumed the meals in the early morning (0800-0830 h). The total study period for an individual was 5 weeks.

primaryOutcome.outcome: Change in plasma interleukin-6 during the postprandial period after the meals.
primaryOutcome.timepoint: Measured at baseline and 1 h, 4 h, and 6 h after the meals.

primaryOutcome.outcome: Change in tumor necrosis factor-alpha during the postprandial period after the meals.
primaryOutcome.timepoint: Measured at baseline and 1 h, 4 h, and 6 h after the meals.

primaryOutcome.outcome: Change in C-reactive protein during the postprandial period after the meals.
primaryOutcome.timepoint: Measured at baseline and 1 h, 4 h, and 6 h after the meals.

primaryOutcome.outcome: Change in interleukin-8 during the postprandial period after the meals.
primaryOutcome.timepoint: Measured at baseline and 1 h, 4 h, and 6 h after the meals.

primaryOutcome.outcome: Change in peroxides during the postprandial period after the meals.
primaryOutcome.timepoint: Measured at baseline and 1 h, 4 h, and 6 h after the meals.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Postprandial changes in plasma insulin, glucose, free fatty acids, and lipids.
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: The outcomes were be measured at baseline and 1 h, 4 h and 6 h after the meals.

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: BMI >=30 kg/m2 and waist circumference >=90 cm for men and >= 88 cm in women. BMI =20-25 kg/m2 and waist circumference < 90 cm for men and <88 cm for women.
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Cigarette smoking; history of cardiovascular disease; chronic infections; serious illnesses; use of medications including hormone replacement therapy. Women using the contraceptive pill and subjects with features of the metabolic syndrome including hypertension and dyslipidaemia will not be excluded.

trial_design.concealment: Allocation schedule held by independent person who was contacted verbally.
trial_design.sequence: Used Mutually Orthogonal Latin Squares Randomisation on www.ams.org/new-in-math/cover/latinII3.html web site.

sponsorship.primarysponsorname: National Heart Foundation of New Zealand

fundingsource.fundingname: National Heart Foundation of New Zealand

ethicsAndSummary.summary: Meals rich in saturated fat increase postprandial levels of pro-inflammatory cytokines in subjects with type 2 diabetes and to a lesser degree in healthy subjects. In the present study we aimed to compare the effect of meals rich in saturated fat and monounsaturated fat and meals rich in bran and potato on pro-inflammatory cytokines and interleukin-8 in obese and nonobese subjects. Frequent acute increases in levels of pro-inflammatory cytokines as a result of regularly eating meals rich in saturated fat may increase the risk of developing diabetes particularly in obese subjects. The principal investigators, data analyst and laboratory staff were blinded to the meal allocation.
